title: 107_s1942
content: The "Biodiesel Promotion Act of 2002" is also known as the Act. It provides incentives for the use of biodiesel as a fuel, including a tax credit for biodiesel used as fuel under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Biodiesel Promotion Act of 2002 offers a biodiesel fuels credit under section 38, based on the biodiesel mixture credit. This credit is determined by the biodiesel mixture rate for each qualified biodiesel mixture and the number of gallons used by the taxpayer. The Biodiesel Promotion Act of 2002 provides a biodiesel fuels credit under section 38 for qualified biodiesel mixtures sold or used by the taxpayer in their trade or business. Casual off-farm production is not eligible for this credit. The Biodiesel Promotion Act of 2002 offers a tax credit for biodiesel mixtures used in the taxpayer's trade or business. Casual off-farm production is not eligible for this credit. The credit amount may be reduced to account for any benefits from other tax exemptions related to biodiesel. The Biodiesel Promotion Act of 2002 provides a tax credit for biodiesel mixtures used in trade or business, excluding casual off-farm production. Biodiesel is defined as monoalkyl esters of long chain fatty acids from various vegetable oils for use in diesel engines, meeting specific registration and testing requirements. The Biodiesel Promotion Act of 2002 offers a tax credit for biodiesel mixtures used in trade or business, excluding casual off-farm production. Biodiesel must meet specific requirements set by the Environmental Protection Agency and the American Society of Testing and Materials D6751. If biodiesel is separated from a qualified mixture or used for purposes other than fuel, a tax is imposed based on the biodiesel mixture rate and the number of gallons used. The Biodiesel Promotion Act of 2002 provides a tax credit for biodiesel mixtures used in trade or business. If biodiesel is used for purposes other than fuel, a tax is imposed based on the biodiesel mixture rate and the number of gallons used. Tax laws apply to the tax imposed as if it were under section 4081. Taxpayers can elect to not apply this section for any taxable year. The Biodiesel Promotion Act of 2002 allows taxpayers to elect to not apply the tax credit for biodiesel fuels for any taxable year. The section will not apply to any fuel sold after December 31, 2012. The credit is treated as part of the general business credit under Section 38(b) of the tax code. The Biodiesel Promotion Act of 2002 allows taxpayers to elect not to apply the biodiesel fuels tax credit after December 31, 2012. The credit is part of the general business credit under Section 38(b) of the tax code, with amendments made to include the biodiesel fuels credit. Additionally, there are conforming amendments regarding the carryback of the biodiesel fuels credit before January 1, 2003. The biodiesel fuels credit under Section 40A can be carried back to a taxable year before January 1, 2003. Amendments are made to various sections of the tax code to include and reference the biodiesel fuels credit. The amendments made by this subsection apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2002. Section 4081 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to include a reduction of motor fuel excise taxes on biodiesel mixtures. The rate of tax for qualified biodiesel mixtures is reduced under certain conditions. The tax rate for diesel fuel used in producing qualified biodiesel mixtures is reduced based on the percentage of biodiesel in the mixture. Definitions for terms used in this subsection align with section 40A. Similar rules from subsection (c) also apply. The tax rate for biodiesel mixtures is reduced based on the biodiesel percentage. Definitions align with section 40A, and rules from subsection (c) also apply. The tax rate for biodiesel mixtures is reduced based on the biodiesel percentage. Amendments to Section 6427 of the Code allow for payment to persons using diesel fuel in producing qualified biodiesel mixtures. Effective from December 31, 2002, to January 1, 2013. Highway Trust Fund transfers are made from the Commodity Credit Corporation funds. The amendments made by this subsection apply to fuel sold between December 31, 2002, and January 1, 2013. Transfers from the Commodity Credit Corporation funds to the Highway Trust Fund are made to offset revenue reductions caused by the amendments. Adjustments are based on Treasury Secretary estimates.
